description: Sequence of letters that often appeared in proper nouns or words including "som", "mer", "oma" and related variations.
Suffixes commonly used in medical terminology, particularly those associated with diseases, conditions, or anatomical features, such as -itis, -osis, -oma, and -ectomy.
Proper nouns and compound words, including place names, brand names, and medical terms, that often end with suffixes such as "-ite", "-oid", "-ola", "-oma", "-ine", and "-ate".
Medical terms and words related to medical testing, diagnosis, and procedures, often including suffixes like -metry, -logy, -osis, -oma, and -scopy, or words related to body parts and substances.

Scientific and formal names of plants, animals, and other organisms, typically in Latin or Greek, often including suffixes such as -idae, -aceae, -ia, -ium, -osis, -itis, -ics, and -omas, used in academic and technical contexts.
Tokens often forming suffixes or prefixes of words, particularly those ending in "-oma", "-rama", "-orama", "anoma-", "-ayama", "-para-", and other similar patterns.
Suffixes forming nouns, primarily those of Greek origin (-om, -ome, -oma), Latin origin (-nom, -nomial), and other less frequent ones (-idom, -man, -strom, -thom, -ponym).

In the given text examples, the activated tokens are often part of scientific, technical, or medical terminology, particularly in fields such as parasitology, microbiology, and medicine. The activated tokens often appear to be suffixes or prefixes of words related to these fields, such as "asis", "osis", "ites", and "oma", or be part of a species name.

Terms related to medical conditions and biological structures, often including words ending in suffixes such as "-cyst", "-oma", "-itis", "-osis", or "-ation", referring to various diseases, growths, and bodily anomalies.
Tokens related to medical terminology, genetic disorders, and cancer research, often including words with the suffixes "-oma" and "-osis", as well as words describing family history and risk factors.
Medical terminology, particularly types of cancer, tumors, or medical conditions, often represented by words with suffixes such as "-oma", "-carcinoma", or "-blastoma".
Familial relationships (grandparent, aunt, uncle), affectionate titles (Opa, Oma, Gandalf, Sifu), and cultural terms of endearment, indicating a familial or close relationship.

Medical conditions or diseases are often indicated by a combination of root words with specific suffixes (e.g. -oma, -al, -osis, -toma) or prefixes, forming complex terms that may describe a particular health condition or disease, such as tumors, cancer, or other medical afflictions.

Medical terms, especially those related to diseases, conditions, and treatments, often containing suffixes such as "-osis", "-itis", "-oma", "-ectomy", or prefixes like "fibro-", "sclero-", and "inter-".
Medical or disease-related terms, often including words ending in "-oma", "-blastoma", "-carcinoma", "-sarcoma", or other specific suffixes and prefixes, and names of conditions or diseases.

Names of diseases, medical conditions, medications, or scientific terms, often including words ending in "-oma", "-iosis", or other specialized suffixes, that are typically used in formal or technical contexts.
Medical terms and specific words related to diseases, health, and medical conditions, often having Greek or Latin roots and/or suffixes (e.g. -itis, -osis, -oma, etc.).

Various medical terms and phrases, mostly related to diseases, conditions, or medical concepts, often featuring suffixes such as "-cyst", "-oma", "-pustule", "-polyp", "-aneurysm", and "-vacuole", which are commonly used in medical terminology.

Medical terminology related to biological conditions, diseases, and body structures, often involving prefixes and suffixes such as "-cyst", "-aneurysm", and "-oma" indicating specific types of growths, tumors, or abnormal formations.
Medical and biological terms, often related to pathology, anatomy, and diseases, and including words that end in -logy, -osis, -oma, and other suffixes common in scientific and medical terminology.
